awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Novel Ultra-Rapid, High Definition, Additive Manufacturing System
awd_abstract_narration:
This SBIR Phase I project will examine a new ultra-rapid 3D printing technology designed to break down important barriers to the future of Additive Manufacturing. The subject is a machine and materials set that can provide exponentially faster object generation at high resolution. This system leverages several familiar technologies in a new way to provide a path for 3D printing, generally considered reserved for the high-tech sectors, to become accessible to everyone. Because the new method is so rapid, detailed, and the materials are so diverse, it is poised to enhance plastics manufacturing profit margins by eliminating mold costs in many cases. In this way, many American business forced to outsource overseas will be able to maintain domestic production and increase the return of manufacturing jobs to the US. In addition, the manufacturing of the consumables will also enhance job creation. When this new method is fully adopted, its use in the medical field will make lifesaving and life enhancing prosthetic, implantable, and pharmaceutical testing applications much more cost effective, fundable by Medicare, benefiting all our citizens. By servicing a higher percentage of the general plastics manufacturing $600B industry, as well as professional designers, engineers, technical professionals, and the medical and scientific community, the new system in its many forms will eventually be of benefit to nearly every industry in the US, increasing the growth and practical value of the 3D market sector.


The subject invention is unique in its use of multiple disciplines simultaneously. As a solid-state system, pressure-biased build material presses up against a glass screen, which is micro-porous, and is laced with the same kind of electronics as are found in flat screen displays. The discrete addressing normally reserved for video images, known as row-and-column refresh rates, is instead used to activate resistive material generating micro-heat spots in this open weave configuration. The heat stimulates the build material to transit the glass and solidify topside, at 1000 dpi resolution, or 1 million droplets per square inch. These high-resolution droplets conjoin and cool, as an entire layer is created at once at 30-120 times a second with no mechanical heads tracking back and forth. The objects should seem to simply appear on the glass at about one to seven vertical inches per minute, depending on the refresh rate, at virtually any planar size, and can be used right away, since no post-curing treatment is needed. Integrating an activated video matrix to build entire cross sections at once, increases speed exponentially. The pores in the glass rely on the known science of Microfluidics, a highly refined means of moving an entire 2D matrix of liquid, to eliminate costly and slow mechanization, and will be studied in this application. Robust and diverse materials have been developed for many embodiments and will be tested. Optimizing first in Multiphysics simulation, and then fabricating a simplified Proof of Concept in Phase I, should provide compelling evidence for continued work on this novel method in Phase II.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Additive Manufacturing has come a long way in the last three decades. However there has been a lag in the entry of 3-D printing into mass manufacturing. The subject invention, called MICROJECTIONTM is poised to provide the solution. 

This SBIR Phase I project successfully proved the concept of this new ultra-rapid MICROJECTION Additive Manufacturing technology, designed to expand the future of Additive Manufacturing into the nearly $700B plastics mass manufacturing industry. The subject system provides exponentially faster object generation at high resolution by leveraging several familiar technologies in a novel way, at speeds like Injection Molding.  

MICROJECTION is new. Think of layers like 3-D printing, think of speed like injection molding  - and then - think again!TM The new process that has just been proven in this Investigation is NOT 3-D printing, and it is NOT injection molding, it IS a new kind of Additive Manufacturing.

It is MICROJECTION Additive Manufacturing, Straight UpTM.

MICROJECTION is unique first in that it is solid state with no tracing heads moving back and forth to deposit layers of an object, its only moving part is the Z-stage that lifts the object as it is built. Objects grow "straight up."

MICROJECTION is also unique in its use of multiple disciplines simultaneously, leveraging a combination of microfluidics, flat panel TV addressing, resistive heaters, and thermoplastics, in a coordinated suite of disciplines generating useful objects at speeds that rival those of injection molding - without the molds.

Microfluidics is a highly refined means of moving an entire 2D matrix of liquid, eliminating costly and slow mechanization. As a microfluidic system, no high pressure is needed, (unlike injection molding, which requires 5000psi and more). In this Investigation, molten nylon was the build fluid, in a manifold under the micro-porous (20 micron) glass screen, laced with the same kind of electronics as are found in flat screen displays. The discrete video addressing normally reserved for video refresh rates is instead used to generate micro-heat resistor spots lining the pores in the glass. The build fluid remained stalled in the capillaries until the heat spots were activated; heat stimulates and thins the liquid plastic.

Microfluidic action generates tiny droplets of build fluid the width of a human hair to form selectively, only where the object is desired to be built. Just a tiny temperature differential in the capillaries permits an entire object cross section's droplets to form at extremely high speed, the refresh rate of a video, at 1000 dpi resolution, (1million droplets per square inch). The droplets are produced so rapidly, form, and conjoin so quickly that objects appear to simply grow out of the glass at visible formation speeds, between one and seven vertical inches per minute. In this way an entire layer is created at once, at 30-200 times a second.

Over this Investigation period of 18 months, a 1000 dpi 1-million-capillaries-per-square-inch Voxel PlatenTM MICROJECTION Proof of Concept system was created, and with it the Inventor successfully produced a three dimensional part of a stair step in crystal clear nylon at speeds heretofore unheard of in AM, but common in Injection Molding. While primitive in its current form, it proves that this concept merits further the development.

A thermoplastic nylon object 1" in diameter and about a half an inch high was "pulled" in under 12 seconds with no inclusions or bubbles in it. The outcome of this investigation was successful and will now inspire the inventor to move forward to seek funding for further development and commercialization.

Because the new method is so rapid, detailed, it is poised to enhance plastics manufacturing profit margins. Thus American business forced to outsource overseas will be able to maintain domestic production and help return manufacturing jobs to the US.

Its thermoplastic embodiment has been proven, which indicates that popular plastics like those already used in the injection molding field can be repurposed in a MICROJECTION system. In fact the system can integrate into existing plastics factories to increase their offerings and reduce expense of making molds. Mold Machining is particularly expensive and can even become cost-prohibitive for short run products. Traditional 3-D printing can also be cost prohibitive for general mass manufacturing. So we believe that with this system plastic production jobs will return to the USA from overseas where cheap labor has taken American jobs.

By servicing a higher percentage of the general plastics manufacturing industry, as well as professional designers, engineers, technical professionals, the medical and scientific communities, the MICROJECTION system in its many forms will eventually be of benefit to nearly every industry in the US, increasing its practical value.

When the MICROJECTION method is fully adopted, its use in medicine will make lifesaving and life enhancing prosthetic, implantable, and pharmaceutical testing applications much more cost effective, fundable by Medicare, benefiting all our citizens.

 

 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 07/21/2019
Modified by: Milton D Meisner
